para.paratext: The search of a motor vehicle, if based on reasonable probable cause,[1] is often valid without consent or a warrant due to their inherently “mobile” nature, which provides an exigent circumstance and additional circumstances are not required.[2] Absent probable cause, two alternatives exist for a warrantless search of a vehicle: police officers may either search a car incident to a lawful arrest of its occupant or perform an inventory search of a car in preparation for impounding.[3]

In New York v. Belton,[4] the United States Supreme Court held that, “when a policeman has made a lawful custodial arrest of the occupant of an automobile, he may, as a contemporaneous incident of that arrest, search the passenger compartment of that automobile.” This also includes any closed containers therein.[5] “The decisive factor in determining whether a search incident to an arrest is valid is ‘whether the arrestee was, at the time of his arrest, a recent occupant of the automobile, not whether the automobile and its contents were in his immediate control at the time of the search.’”[6]

The vehicle searched must somehow be related to the arrest. Thus, a vehicle search where a driver was standing next to his car drinking a beer in a park in violation of a county ordinance was not “incident to arrest”[7] because the vehicle itself was unconnected to both the offense and the arrest.

The requirement that the search be contemporaneous with the arrest does not mean that the officer cannot take any other action prior to the search, but that any time lapse be reasonable. Thus, an automobile search was held to be sufficiently “contemporaneous” to a motorist's arrest, despite the police officer writing out two traffic tickets for the driver before conducting the search.[8]

Also, a search incident to arrest was valid when the defendant was handcuffed and placed in a patrol car before the officer conducted the search.[9] However, the United States Supreme Court held in Arizona v. Gant[10] that a search of a defendant's automobile was unreasonable, when the defendant was handcuffed in a patrol car during the search, because a vehicle search would not yield evidence of the driving on a suspended license offense for which defendant was arrested and there was no risk of the defendant destroying evidence.[11] In Gant, the court expressly narrowed its holding in Belton by specifying that a police officer can search an automobile incident to arrest only if “(1) the arrestee is within reaching distance of the vehicle at the time of the search, or (2) the officer has reason to believe that the vehicle contains evidence of the offense of arrest.”[12]

Early Georgia cases held that vehicle may not be searched incident to the arrest of the driver for a traffic violation. In Rowland v. State,[13] the Georgia Court of Appeals held a search of defendant's vehicle unlawful under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-1 because it was not conducted incident to his arrest for running a stop light.

Later in Howe v. State,[14] the court upheld a vehicle search to obtain evidence of drug use and the admission of evidence of marijuana found as a result of the search when the defendant was charged with driving under the influence.[15] In so doing, the court recognized its holding in Rowland, but acknowledged that the United States Supreme Court had “ameliorated the basis for the rule.”

A vehicle may not be stopped and searched on the sole pretext of traffic violations (without a warranted arrest) unless additional facts lead the officer to believe that there is contraband in the vehicle.[16]

In U.S. v. Ross,[17] the United States Supreme Court held that, when officers legitimately stop an automobile and have probable cause to believe that contraband is concealed therein, the search of the vehicle can be as broad as though it were conducted under a search warrant. Containers in the trunk may also be searched.[18]

When an accused disavows ownership or other legitimate possessory interest in the vehicle searched, he has no legitimate expectation of privacy therein, and a search violates no right.[19] The Georgia Court of Appeals held in Henderson v. State[20] that a defendant in a drug possession case lacked standing to contest the search and seizure of the contents of a bag found in a vehicle based on his denial of any legal or equitable interest or right of temporary possession of the automobile or the bag. At the scene of his arrest, defendant said that the car belonged to his cousin. When police asked what he had just thrown into the car, the defendant said, “Nothing,” and when police asked what was in the bag, he said, “What bag?” The court held that the Fourth Amendment right is personal and cannot be asserted vicariously.[21]
A locked, impounded automobile may be inventoried by police even if it has to be forcibly entered.[22] This is true even if some less intrusive method might achieve the same purpose.[23]

In an inventory search, a police officer “may ordinarily inspect the glove compartment, the trunk, on top of the seats as well as under the front seats, and the floor of the automobile. Inspection of these areas is reasonable because these are common locations for the owner or occupant of an automobile to place items of personalty.”[24]

In State v. Evans,[25] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that an officer may unlock and inventory contents in the trunk of a vehicle, including searching an unlocked container, in the absence of probable cause when the search was conducted pursuant to standard procedure.

Existence of a standard procedure is relevant to determining the validity of the search, but is not determinative.[26] In each instance, the validity of an inventory search will turn on the reasonableness of the police conduct under the circumstances.[27]

There must be some necessity for the police to impound a vehicle to be valid,[28] but the impoundment need not be absolutely necessary as long as it was reasonably necessary under the circumstances.[29]

The Georgia Court of Appeals held an impoundment and search invalid in State v. McCranie[30] where the defendant was arrested on his own property and police made an “inventory” search of the trunk of his automobile before impoundment.[31]

The search of a legally parked automobile half a block away from the scene of the arrest was not a valid inventory search.[32] Georgia courts have held that where the “driver is arrested and a reliable friend is present who may be authorized and capable of removing the vehicle, or where the arrestee expresses some preference for a private towing service,” the vehicle cannot be validly impounded.[33]

If, however, “a driver is arrested and removed from his vehicle, and the vehicle is on a highway or other public property, and there is no third person present to whom it is or might properly be turned over, or for some other sufficient reason a decision to impound it is properly made, and where in connection with such impoundment an ‘inventory search’ is a recognized and routine procedure, contraband which appears in plain view in the course of such inventory is properly seized, and may be introduced in evidence on a subsequent trial for its possession.”[34]

U.S. v. Ross, 456 U.S. 798, 809, 102 S. Ct. 2157, 72 L. Ed. 2d 572 (1982); Benton v. State, 240 Ga. App. 243, 522 S.E.2d 726 (1999); Miller v. State, 127 Ga. App. 248, 192 S.E.2d 915 (1972); State v. Bradley, 138 Ga. App. 800, 227 S.E.2d 776 (1976); Glover v. State, 139 Ga. App. 162, 227 S.E.2d 921 (1976); Bramblett v. State, 239 Ga. 336, 236 S.E.2d 580 (1977); South Dakota v. Opperman, 428 U.S. 364, 96 S. Ct. 3092, 49 L. Ed. 2d 1000 (1976).
See Hall v. State, 176 Ga. App. 428, 336 S.E.2d 291 (1985).
See also Radowick v. State, 145 Ga. App. 231, 244 S.E.2d 346 (1978) (auto search invalid, but the case includes an excellent discussion of consent searches).

See also Ridgeway v. State, 205 Ga. App. 218, 422 S.E.2d 4 (1992) (noting that officers could lawfully conduct warrantless search of trunk after $4,000 in cash, a set of scales, and suspected cocaine residue had already been lawfully discovered during search of appellant's person and in passenger compartment of automobile); Scott v. State, 277 Ga. App. 126, 625 S.E.2d 526 (2006) (holding that officer had probable cause to believe that defendant's vehicle contained contraband and was justified in conducting a warrantless search of vehicle).

The cases permitting a warrantless search of an automobile based on probable cause were extended to a mobile “motor home” in California v. Carney, 471 U.S. 386, 105 S. Ct. 2066, 85 L. Ed. 2d 406 (1985).
State v. Howard, 264 Ga. App. 691, 592 S.E.2d 88 (2003).

In Maddox v. State, 188 Ga. App. 883, 374 S.E.2d 810 (1988), Judge Beasley's concurrence contains a good discussion of the difference between inventory searches, searches incident to arrest, and probable cause to search. There, the search was upheld as incident to arrest, but Judge Beasley argued that it should have been upheld as a valid inventory search.

Vega v. State, 236 Ga. App. 319, 512 S.E.2d 65 (1999) (“Because defendant's gym bag was found in Chesley's car just after she was lawfully arrested, it was subject to being searched incident to that arrest,” citing Belton, State v. Elliott, 205 Ga. App. 345, 422 S.E.2d 58 (1992)).
State v. Howard, 264 Ga. App. 691, 592 S.E.2d 88, 92 (2003) (quoting Scoggins v. State, 248 Ga. App. 1, 2, 545 S.E.2d 19 (2001)).
Oswell v. State, 181 Ga. App. 35, 351 S.E.2d 221(1986) (discussing Strobhert v. State, 165 Ga. App. 515, 301 S.E.2d 681 (1983)).
Oswell v. State, 181 Ga. App. 35, 351 S.E.2d 221(1986).
Richardson v. State, 232 Ga. App. 398, 501 S.E.2d 885 (1998).

Arizona v. Gant, 556 U.S. 332, 129 S. Ct. 1710, 173 L. Ed. 2d 485, 47 A.L.R. Fed. 2d 657 (2009). Because police could not reasonably have believed either that Gant could have accessed his car at the time of the search or that evidence of the offense for which he was arrested might have been found therein, the search in this case was unreasonable.
Rowland v. State, 117 Ga. App. 577, 161 S.E.2d 422 (1968).

Howe v. State, 132 Ga. App. 840, 209 S.E.2d 258 (1974) (citing Cady v. Dombrowski, 413 U.S. 433, 93 S. Ct. 2523, 37 L. Ed. 2d 706 (1973); U.S. v. Robinson, 414 U.S. 218, 94 S. Ct. 467, 38 L. Ed. 2d 427 (1973); Gustafson v. Florida, 414 U.S. 260, 94 S. Ct. 488, 38 L. Ed. 2d 456 (1973)).
Howe v. State, 132 Ga. App. 840, 209 S.E.2d 258 (1974).
Cook v. State, 136 Ga. App. 908, 222 S.E.2d 656 (1975).

See Deych v. State, 188 Ga. App. 901, 902, 374 S.E.2d 753 (1988); Henderson v. State, 211 Ga. App. 102, 438 S.E.2d 181 (1993); Nation v. State, 252 Ga. App. 620, 556 S.E.2d 196 (2001); State v. Graddy, 262 Ga. App. 98, 585 S.E.2d 147 (2003).
Henderson v. State, 211 Ga. App. 102, 438 S.E.2d 181 (1993).
Henderson v. State, 211 Ga. App. 102, 438 S.E.2d 181 (1993).
See South Dakota v. Opperman, 428 U.S. 364, 96 S. Ct. 3092, 49 L. Ed. 2d 1000 (1976).

See also Cady v. Dombrowski, 413 U.S. 433, 93 S. Ct. 2523, 37 L. Ed. 2d 706 (1973); Hunter v. State, 127 Ga. App. 664, 194 S.E.2d 680 (1972); Denson v. State, 128 Ga. App. 456, 197 S.E.2d 156 (1973); Highland v. State, 144 Ga. App. 594, 241 S.E.2d 477 (1978); State v. Izquierdo, 160 Ga. App. 33, 285 S.E.2d 769 (1981); Fortson v. State, 262 Ga. 3, 412 S.E.2d 833 (1992); State v. King, 237 Ga. App. 729, 516 S.E.2d 580 (1999); Johnson v. State, 263 Ga. App. 443, 587 S.E.2d 775 (2003); Stringer v. State, 285 Ga. App. 599, 647 S.E.2d 310 (2007).
Colorado v. Bertine, 479 U.S. 367, 107 S. Ct. 738, 93 L. Ed. 2d 739 (1987).
Arnold v. State, 155 Ga. App. 581, 582, 271 S.E.2d 714 (1980) (quoting U.S. v. Edwards, 577 F.2d 883, 894 (5th Cir. 1978)).
State v. Evans, 181 Ga. App. 422, 352 S.E.2d 599 (1986).
State v. Lowe, 224 Ga. App. 228, 480 S.E.2d 611 (1997).
See, e.g., State v. Howard, 264 Ga. App. 691, 592 S.E.2d 88 (2003).
State v. Lowe, 224 Ga. App. 228, 480 S.E.2d 611 (1997).
See also Florida v. Wells, 495 U.S. 1, 110 S. Ct. 1632, 109 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1990).
State v. Lowe, 224 Ga. App. 228, 480 S.E.2d 611 (1997).
See also Stringer v. State, 285 Ga. App. 599, 647 S.E.2d 310 (2007).
Gaston v. State, 257 Ga. App. 480, 483, 571 S.E.2d 477 (2002); State v. Howard, 264 Ga. App. 691, 592 S.E.2d 88 (2003).

“The determinative inquiry, therefore, is whether the impoundment was reasonably necessary under the circumstances, not whether it was absolutely necessary.” Teal v. State, 282 Ga. 319, 328, 647 S.E.2d 15 (2007) (quoting Carlisle v. State, 278 Ga. App. 528, 529–530, 629 S.E.2d 512 (2006)).
State v. McCranie, 137 Ga. App. 369, 223, 223 S.E.2d 765 (1976).
See also State v. Travitz, 140 Ga. App. 351, 231 S.E.2d 127 (1976).
Improper impounding also resulted in invalid searches in State v. Ludvicek, 147 Ga. App. 784, 250 S.E.2d 503 (1978); Rohrig v. State, 148 Ga. App. 869, 253 S.E.2d 253 (1979).

In Mooney v. State, 243 Ga. 373, 254 S.E.2d 337 (1979) (abrogated on other grounds by, Horton v. California, 496 U.S. 128, 110 S. Ct. 2301, 110 L. Ed. 2d 112 (1990)), the principle of the inventory search was extended to luggage.
An inventory search was valid in Garner v. State, 154 Ga. App. 839, 269 S.E.2d 912 (1980).

See also State v. Gilchrist, 174 Ga. App. 499, 330 S.E.2d 430 (1985); Pierce v. State, 194 Ga. App. 481, 391 S.E.2d 3 (1990); Colzie v. State, 257 Ga. App. 691, 572 S.E.2d 43 (2002) (where driver was apprehended very late in the evening, car apparently did not have insurance, and area was unsafe, impoundment was reasonable).
State v. Creel, 142 Ga. App. 158, 235 S.E.2d 628 (1977).
Highland v. State, 144 Ga. App. 594, 594, 241 S.E.2d 477 (1978).

See also, e.g., Pierce v. State, 134 Ga. App. 14, 213 S.E.2d 162 (1975), where the vehicle was validly impounded and inventoried following the arrest of a driver for driving while under the influence, search was sustained.
